newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Ringgit hits 16-month low at 2.55 a dollar.
newsitem.headline: Ringgit hits 16-month low at 2.55 a dollar.

text.p: The ringgit hit a 16-month low against the dollar in early trade on selling pressure, with Bank Negara Malaysia surprisingly staying out of the market, dealers said.
At 0100 GMT, the ringgit was at 2.5500 to a dollar, its lowest level since February 29, 1996. It closed 2.5042/52 in Kuala Lumpur on Friday.
"Hong Kong, Sydney and Singapore are heavily selling the ringgit after talk that Bank Negara has lifted orders to sell the dollar," said a European bank dealer in Singapore.
He said Bank Negara was heard to have sold the dollar around 2.5500. "But I think Negara was in just to slow down the fall rather than stop the flow," he said.
Dealers said with the market still long dollars, there is room for the ringgit to go lower.
They said Bank Negara may be allowing market forces to dictate the spot's value rather than defend the ringgit aggressively "for a lost cause."
The central bank spent more than $1 billion last week to help the ringgit.

Dealers said Philippines Central Bank's move to allow the peso to trade in a wider range against the dollar, which is seen as a de facto devaluation, has exerted pressures on the ringgit as well as the rupiah.
Dealers said they expected dollar/ringgit trading to remain volatile within a 2.5250-2.5650 range.
